In AJ 20:17-96 Josephus tells the history of the royal House of Adiabene and its relationship to Judaism.

On Iranian names in rabbinic literature see Introduction 1.4.1. So in the Vilna print (and other mss). The many versions of the name point to its unstable nature and to the fact that it was unknown to scribes, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1.

So in the Munich 95 Ms to bKet 65a, see above, n. 2. The interchange of ו and י is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.7.1.
Appears in rabbinic literature as the wife of a prominent rabbi, and daughter of another rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.
Was the wife of Abbaye (1), who died in 338 CE, according to ShGa § 173, see Introduction 8.2.1.
See previous note.

There are problems with identifying this woman as Jewish. However in bNid 20b she sets a question to the sages that is only of interest to Jews and in Christian sources Sāpōr’s mother is described as a descendent of Jews, see J. Neusner, A History of the Jews in Babylonia 4 (Leiden 1969) 36. The name is also theophoric and pagan, see Introduction 6.8.
Was King Shapur II’s mother. These are his dates (from birth to death).

person.note: Both forms appear on the sarcophgus. On this name see vol. 1, Sadain (1) I/F, p. 356.

In Aramaic – מלכתא. This identification was suggested by C. Clermont-Ganneau, “Le temple de Baal Marcod a Dier al-Kal‘a,” Recueil d’archéologie orientale 1 (1885-8) 107-8. Although rejected by Klein, Corpus Inscriptionum, 26, it makes sense. It is the queen’s Semitic name, and the tomb were it was found is beyond doubt the tomb of Helene, as described by both Josephus (BJ 5:55, 119, 147) and Pausanias Description of Greece, 7:16:5 (see GLAJJ II, 196).

In AJ 20:17 Josephus claims that she converted to Judaism (εἰς τὰ ̓Ιουδαίων ἔθη τὸν βίον μετέβαλον) and then goes on to tell how it happened, see Introduction 6.1.2. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Sadain [1]), p. 356, but not included in the statistics.

This is my suggested interpretation of the text that reads: הרמסדר טרדי. I assume the scribe forgot to insert a בן or בר (son). I cannot imagine that טרדי is the second name of הרמסדר because the latter is female, as its appearance in the beginning of this bowl indicates (טרדי בת אוני) and the former is male, as the other appearances of this name in this corpus indicate. I assume that the amulet was written to protect mother (טרדי בת אוני) and son (הרמסדד [בר] טרדי).
